title: Polarisation of Light - Multiple Choice Questions
subtitle: NIOS Class 12 Physics - Module 6: Wave Phenomena and Light

questions.question: What is polarisation of light?
options: The splitting of white light into colors
The phenomenon in which vibrations of light get confined to a particular plane containing the direction of propagation
The bending of light around obstacles
The change in speed of light through different media
questions.explanation: Polarisation of light is the phenomenon in which the electric field vibrations of light are confined to a particular plane containing the direction of propagation. This proved conclusively that light is a transverse wave.

questions.question: What does polarisation of light prove about the nature of light?
options: Light is a longitudinal wave
Light travels in straight lines
Light is a transverse wave
Light is a stream of particles
questions.explanation: Polarisation of light conclusively establishes that light is a transverse wave. In longitudinal waves (like sound), particles oscillate along the direction of propagation, so polarisation is not possible. The fact that light can be polarised proves its transverse nature.

questions.question: In the activity with two cardboard slits S₁ and S₂, why do waves pass through both when both slits are vertical?
options: Because the slits are aligned
Because the vibrations in the wave are vertical, parallel to both vertical slits
Because the wave amplitude increases
Because the medium transmits all vibrations
questions.explanation: When both slits are vertical, the vibrations in the waves generated by moving the hand up and down are also vertical. These vertical vibrations can pass through the vertical slit S₂, so waves are observed beyond S₂.

questions.question: In the cardboard slit activity, what happens when S₁ is vertical and S₂ is horizontal?
options: More waves pass through S₂
Waves are partially blocked
No waves pass beyond S₂
Waves change color
questions.explanation: When S₁ is vertical (waves with vertical vibrations) and S₂ is horizontal, the waves cannot pass through S₂ because the vibrations are in a plane at right angles to the horizontal slit S₂. This demonstrates that waves have a definite plane of vibration.

questions.question: What is a polaroid?
options: A type of lens that focuses light
A material made of crystals lined up to transmit light vibrating in one specific plane
A device that splits light into colors
A reflective surface
questions.explanation: A polaroid is a thin sheet made from tiny crystals of quinine iodosulphate lined up in the same direction in nitrocellulose. These dichroic crystals transmit light vibrating in one specific plane and absorb light vibrating in the perpendicular plane.

questions.question: What happens when unpolarised light passes through a polaroid?
options: Light intensity remains the same
The light becomes linearly polarised (plane polarised)
The light color changes
The light refracts
questions.explanation: When unpolarised light passes through a polaroid, only the component of light vibrating in the transmission plane of the polaroid passes through. The emergent light is linearly polarised (plane polarised) with vibrations confined to a single plane.

questions.question: What happens when unpolarised light is reflected from a glass or water surface?
options: It remains unpolarised
It becomes completely plane polarised
It is partially plane polarised
It loses all intensity
questions.explanation: When unpolarised light is reflected from a transparent material like glass or water, the reflected light is partially plane polarised. Complete polarisation occurs only when the incident angle equals the polarising angle.

questions.question: What is the polarising angle?
options: The angle between the incident and reflected rays
The angle at which completely polarised light is reflected
The angle between the normal and the surface
The angle between the refracted and incident rays
questions.explanation: The polarising angle (also called Brewster's angle) is the specific angle of incidence at which the reflected light becomes completely plane polarised. At this angle, there is maximum polarisation of the reflected light.

questions.question: What is Brewster's law?
options: μ = sin i / cos i
μ = tan i_p
μ = sin i_p / cos i_p
μ = cos i_p / sin i_p
questions.explanation: Brewster's law states that μ = tan i_p, where μ is the refractive index of the material and i_p is the polarising angle. This relation is derived using Snell's law and the condition that reflected and refracted rays are perpendicular at polarising angle.

questions.question: What is the relationship between reflected and refracted rays at the polarising angle?
options: They are parallel
They are perpendicular to each other
They make 45° with each other
They are in the same direction
questions.explanation: At the polarising angle, the reflected and refracted rays are at right angles (90°) to each other. This geometric condition leads to Brewster's law and complete polarisation of reflected light.

questions.question: For an air-water interface, what is the polarising angle?
questions.explanation: For an air-water interface, the polarising angle i_p = 53°. This means when sunlight is 37° above the horizontal (so the incident angle is 53°), light reflected from a calm pond or lake will be completely linearly polarised.

questions.question: What practical application does Brewster's law have in daily life?
options: Designing microscopes
Reducing glare from reflective surfaces using polaroid sunglasses
Creating rainbows
Focusing light beams
questions.explanation: Brewster's law is applied in polaroid sunglasses and coatings on lenses. Polaroid materials reduce glare by absorbing the polarised component of light reflected from smooth surfaces like water or roads, improving visibility and reducing discomfort.

questions.question: What are dichroic crystals?
options: Crystals that split light into two colors
Crystals that transmit light in one direction and absorb it in the perpendicular direction
Crystals that double the intensity of light
Crystals that reflect all light
questions.explanation: Dichroic crystals transmit light vibrations along one axis and absorb light vibrations along the perpendicular axis. This property is used in polaroids where dichroic crystals are aligned in the same direction to create polarising material.

questions.question: How are polaroid coatings made?
options: By polishing glass
By coating with oil
By embedding dichroic crystals aligned in the same direction in nitrocellulose
By reflecting light multiple times
questions.explanation: Polaroid coatings are made from tiny dichroic crystals (quinine iodosulphate) that are all lined up in the same direction embedded in a sheet of nitrocellulose. This alignment ensures that only light vibrating in the polaroid's transmission plane passes through.

questions.question: What is the effect of using polaroid filters in photography?
options: Increases image brightness
Reduces glare and reveals details that would otherwise be hidden
Changes the color of the image
Increases the depth of field
questions.explanation: Polaroid filters in photography reduce glare caused by polarised light reflected from smooth surfaces. By absorbing the polarised component, these filters reveal details and provide better contrast in the photograph that would otherwise be hidden by glare.

questions.question: What is a polarimeter used for?
options: Measuring the speed of light
Determining the refractive index of materials
Quality control in sugar industry by measuring polarised light
Producing plane polarised light
questions.explanation: A polarimeter is used for quality control in the sugar industry. It measures the rotation of plane polarised light as it passes through a sugar solution, which depends on the concentration and purity of sugar.

questions.question: What happens when two polaroids are placed with their transmission axes perpendicular to each other?
options: Maximum light passes through
Light intensity is reduced to half
No light passes through (light is completely blocked)
Light color changes
questions.explanation: When two polaroids are placed with their transmission axes perpendicular (at 90°) to each other, light that is polarised by the first polaroid cannot pass through the second because the second polaroid's axis is perpendicular to the polarisation direction. Result: no light emerges.

questions.question: What is the angle between the transmission axes of two polaroids needed to block light completely?
questions.explanation: Light is blocked completely when the angle between the transmission axes of two polaroids is 90° (or 270°). At this angle, the polarised light from the first polaroid is perpendicular to the transmission axis of the second, resulting in no light emerging.

questions.question: Can sound waves in air exhibit polarisation?
options: Yes, sound waves are always polarised
Yes, sound waves can be polarised by special devices
No, sound waves are longitudinal and cannot be polarised
Only certain frequencies of sound can be polarised
questions.explanation: Sound waves in air cannot exhibit polarisation because they are longitudinal waves. Polarisation is a phenomenon unique to transverse waves like light. In longitudinal waves, particles oscillate along the direction of propagation, so there is no concept of a polarisation plane.

questions.question: Is it possible for the direction of motion of a wave to lie in the plane of polarisation?
options: Yes, always
Yes, for longitudinal waves only
No, for transverse waves the direction of motion (propagation) is always perpendicular to the plane of polarisation
No, for any type of wave
questions.explanation: For transverse waves like light, the direction of propagation (motion) is always perpendicular to the plane of polarisation. The plane of polarisation contains the direction of vibration and the direction of propagation, not the actual motion of the wave.

questions.question: What does the term 'plane polarised' or 'linearly polarised' light mean?
options: Light that travels in a plane path
Light whose vibrations are confined to a single plane containing the direction of propagation
Light that has been reflected from a plane surface
Light that travels in a straight line
questions.explanation: Plane polarised (or linearly polarised) light is light whose electric field vibrations are confined to a single plane containing the direction of propagation. After passing through a polaroid, unpolarised light becomes plane polarised.

questions.question: Why is glare produced when light is reflected from a smooth surface like water?
options: Because water absorbs some light
Because the reflected light is partially polarised, causing discomfort to the eye
Because water acts as a lens
Because the light intensity increases
questions.explanation: Glare from smooth surfaces like water is produced due to reflected light that is partially or completely plane polarised (depending on angle). This polarised light can cause discomfort to the eyes. Polaroid sunglasses reduce this glare by absorbing the polarised component.

questions.question: At what angle of incidence is the reflected light completely polarised for an air-glass interface (n=1.5)?
questions.explanation: Using Brewster's law: i_p = arctan(μ) = arctan(1.5) ≈ 56.3°. At this polarising angle, the reflected light from the air-glass interface becomes completely plane polarised.

questions.question: What is the principle of superposition in the context of polarised light?
options: Two plane polarised lights always add constructively
Plane polarised light cannot be superposed
Two light waves can superpose regardless of their polarisation states
Two plane polarised lights superpose based on their relative polarisation directions
questions.explanation: When two plane polarised light waves superpose, the result depends on their relative polarisation directions. If the polarisation planes are parallel, superposition occurs normally. If perpendicular, they do not interact significantly, and if at an angle, partial superposition occurs.

questions.question: How does the refractive index of a material relate to its polarising angle according to Brewster's law?
options: They are inversely proportional
The refractive index equals the tangent of the polarising angle
The refractive index equals the sine of the polarising angle
They are independent of each other
questions.explanation: According to Brewster's law: μ = tan(i_p), where μ is the refractive index and i_p is the polarising angle. This relationship shows that materials with different refractive indices have different polarising angles. For example, water (n=1.33) has i_p≈53°, while glass (n=1.5) has i_p≈56.3°.
